page.title: 03Places Of Worship
page.content: There are four{places of worship still in use in our area and one that has been converted into a house. The{church of St.James and St.Mary {Magdalene,Husborne Crawley,}dates from 1219 and is of the late Saxon/Norman period.Its tower is unusual for its green sandstone.Christian worship has been on this site for almost 8OO years.The {church of St. Botolph in {Aspley Guise}dates from at least 1223 but much of the original stonework has been replaced,mainly around 18O6. {St.Mary's}Catholic church dates from 1955 and has 52O members.It's still building up a tradition but is already active in local life.Aspley Guise{ {Evangelical Free Church}was built in 1843 and is in the Square.Finally the old{Methodist Chapel}built in 1813 is now a house but still has its original oak doors,beams and windows.{LAURA.}
